trans-unit.source: Operations for Your Azure Rights Management Tenant Key
trans-unit.target: Operations for Your Azure Rights Management Tenant Key

trans-unit.source: Depending on your tenant key topology (Microsoft-managed or customer-managed), you have different levels of control and responsibility for your Microsoft Azure Rights Management (Azure RMS) tenant key after it is implemented.
trans-unit.target: Depending on your tenant key topology (Microsoft-managed or customer-managed), you have different levels of control and responsibility for your Microsoft Azure Rights Management (Azure RMS) tenant key after it is implemented.

trans-unit.source: When you manage your own tenant key, this is often referred to as bring your own key (BYOK).
trans-unit.target: When you manage your own tenant key, this is often referred to as bring your own key (BYOK).

trans-unit.source: For more information about this scenario and how to choose between the two tenant key topologies, see <link><linkText>Planning and Implementing Your Azure Rights Management Tenant Key</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about this scenario and how to choose between the two tenant key topologies, see <link><linkText>Planning and Implementing Your Azure Rights Management Tenant Key</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: The following table identifies which operations you can do, depending on the topology that you’ve chosen for your Azure RMS tenant key.
trans-unit.target: The following table identifies which operations you can do, depending on the topology that you’ve chosen for your Azure RMS tenant key.

trans-unit.source: Lifecycle operation
trans-unit.target: Lifecycle operation

trans-unit.source: Microsoft-managed (default)
trans-unit.target: Microsoft-managed (default)

trans-unit.source: Customer-managed (BYOK)
trans-unit.target: Customer-managed (BYOK)

trans-unit.source: Revoke your tenant key
trans-unit.target: Revoke your tenant key

trans-unit.source: No (automatic)
trans-unit.target: No (automatic)

trans-unit.source: No (automatic)
trans-unit.target: No (automatic)

trans-unit.source: Re-key your tenant key
trans-unit.target: Re-key your tenant key

trans-unit.source: Yes
trans-unit.target: Yes

trans-unit.source: Yes
trans-unit.target: Yes

trans-unit.source: Backup and recover your tenant key
trans-unit.target: Backup and recover your tenant key

trans-unit.source: No
trans-unit.target: No

trans-unit.source: Yes
trans-unit.target: Yes

trans-unit.source: Export your tenant key
trans-unit.target: Export your tenant key

trans-unit.source: Yes
trans-unit.target: Yes

trans-unit.source: No
trans-unit.target: No

trans-unit.source: Respond to a breach
trans-unit.target: Respond to a breach

trans-unit.source: Yes
trans-unit.target: Yes

trans-unit.source: Yes
trans-unit.target: Yes

trans-unit.source: After you have identified which topology you have implemented, use one of the following sections for more information about these operations for your Azure RMS tenant key.
trans-unit.target: After you have identified which topology you have implemented, use one of the following sections for more information about these operations for your Azure RMS tenant key.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Microsoft-managed: Tenant key lifecycle operations
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Microsoft-managed: Tenant key lifecycle operations

trans-unit.source: If Microsoft manages your tenant key for Azure Rights Management (the default), use the following sections for more information about the lifecycle operations that are relevant to this topology:
trans-unit.target: If Microsoft manages your tenant key for Azure Rights Management (the default), use the following sections for more information about the lifecycle operations that are relevant to this topology:

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Revoke your tenant key</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Revoke your tenant key</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Re-key your tenant key</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Re-key your tenant key</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Backup and recover your tenant key</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Backup and recover your tenant key</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Export your tenant key</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Export your tenant key</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Respond to a breach</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Respond to a breach</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Revoke your tenant key
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Revoke your tenant key

trans-unit.source: When you unsubscribe from Azure RMS, Azure RMS stops using your tenant key and no action is needed from you.
trans-unit.target: When you unsubscribe from Azure RMS, Azure RMS stops using your tenant key and no action is needed from you.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Re-key your tenant key
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Re-key your tenant key

trans-unit.source: Re-keying is also known as rolling your key.
trans-unit.target: Re-keying is also known as rolling your key.

trans-unit.source: Do not re-key your tenant key unless it’s really necessary.
trans-unit.target: Do not re-key your tenant key unless it’s really necessary.

trans-unit.source: Older clients, such as Office 2010, were not designed to handle key changes gracefully.
trans-unit.target: Older clients, such as Office 2010, were not designed to handle key changes gracefully.

trans-unit.source: In this scenario, you must clear the RMS state on computers by using Group Policy or an equivalent mechanism.
trans-unit.target: In this scenario, you must clear the RMS state on computers by using Group Policy or an equivalent mechanism.

trans-unit.source: However, there are some legitimate events that may force you to re-key your tenant key.
trans-unit.target: However, there are some legitimate events that may force you to re-key your tenant key.

trans-unit.source: For example:
trans-unit.target: For example:

trans-unit.source: Your company has split into two or more companies.
trans-unit.target: Your company has split into two or more companies.

trans-unit.source: When you re-key your tenant key, the new company will not have access to new content that your employees publish.
trans-unit.target: When you re-key your tenant key, the new company will not have access to new content that your employees publish.

trans-unit.source: They can access the old content if they have a copy of the old tenant key.
trans-unit.target: They can access the old content if they have a copy of the old tenant key.

trans-unit.source: You believe the master copy of your tenant key (the copy in your possession) was compromised.
trans-unit.target: You believe the master copy of your tenant key (the copy in your possession) was compromised.

trans-unit.source: You can re-key your tenant key by calling Microsoft Customer Support Services (CSS) and proving that you are the tenant administrator.
trans-unit.target: You can re-key your tenant key by calling Microsoft Customer Support Services (CSS) and proving that you are the tenant administrator.

trans-unit.source: When you re-key your tenant key, new content is protected by using the new tenant key.
trans-unit.target: When you re-key your tenant key, new content is protected by using the new tenant key.

trans-unit.source: This happens in a phased manner, so for a period of time, some new content will continue to be protected with the old tenant key.
trans-unit.target: This happens in a phased manner, so for a period of time, some new content will continue to be protected with the old tenant key.

trans-unit.source: Previously protected content stays protected to your old tenant key.
trans-unit.target: Previously protected content stays protected to your old tenant key.

trans-unit.source: To support this scenario, Azure RMS retains your old tenant key so that it can issue licenses for old content.
trans-unit.target: To support this scenario, Azure RMS retains your old tenant key so that it can issue licenses for old content.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Backup and recover your tenant key
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Backup and recover your tenant key

trans-unit.source: Microsoft is responsible for backing up your tenant key and no action is required from you.
trans-unit.target: Microsoft is responsible for backing up your tenant key and no action is required from you.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Export your tenant key
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Export your tenant key

trans-unit.source: You can export your Azure RMS configuration and tenant key by following the instructions in these three steps:
trans-unit.target: You can export your Azure RMS configuration and tenant key by following the instructions in these three steps:

trans-unit.source: Step 1: Initiate export
trans-unit.target: Step 1: Initiate export

trans-unit.source: To do this, contact Microsoft Customer Service Support (CSS).
trans-unit.target: To do this, contact Microsoft Customer Service Support (CSS).

trans-unit.source: You must prove you are an administrator for your Azure RMS tenant.
trans-unit.target: You must prove you are an administrator for your Azure RMS tenant.

trans-unit.source: Step 2: Wait for verification
trans-unit.target: Step 2: Wait for verification

trans-unit.source: Microsoft verifies that your request to release your RMS tenant key is legitimate.
trans-unit.target: Microsoft verifies that your request to release your RMS tenant key is legitimate.

trans-unit.source: This process can take up to 3 weeks.
trans-unit.target: This process can take up to 3 weeks.

trans-unit.source: Step 3: Receive key instructions from CSS
trans-unit.target: Step 3: Receive key instructions from CSS

trans-unit.source: Microsoft Customer Support Services (CSS) will send you your Azure RMS configuration and tenant key as encrypted in a password-protected file that has a .tpd file name extension.
trans-unit.target: Microsoft Customer Support Services (CSS) will send you your Azure RMS configuration and tenant key as encrypted in a password-protected file that has a .tpd file name extension.

trans-unit.source: To do this, CSS first sends you (as the person who initiated the export) a tool by email.
trans-unit.target: To do this, CSS first sends you (as the person who initiated the export) a tool by email.

trans-unit.source: You must run the tool from a command prompt as follows:
trans-unit.target: You must run the tool from a command prompt as follows:

trans-unit.source: This generates an RSA key pair and saves the public and private halves as files in the current folder.
trans-unit.target: This generates an RSA key pair and saves the public and private halves as files in the current folder.

trans-unit.source: For example: PublicKey-FA29D0FE-5049-4C8E-931B-96C6152B0441.txt and PrivateKey-FA29D0FE-5049-4C8E-931B-96C6152B0441.txt.
trans-unit.target: For example: PublicKey-FA29D0FE-5049-4C8E-931B-96C6152B0441.txt and PrivateKey-FA29D0FE-5049-4C8E-931B-96C6152B0441.txt.

trans-unit.source: Respond to the email from CSS, attaching the file that has a name that starts with PublicKey.
trans-unit.target: Respond to the email from CSS, attaching the file that has a name that starts with PublicKey.

trans-unit.source: CSS will next send you a TPD file as an .xml file that is encrypted with your RSA key.
trans-unit.target: CSS will next send you a TPD file as an .xml file that is encrypted with your RSA key.

trans-unit.source: Copy this file to the same folder as you ran the AadrmTpd tool originally, and run the tool again, using your file that starts with PrivateKey and the file from CSS.
trans-unit.target: Copy this file to the same folder as you ran the AadrmTpd tool originally, and run the tool again, using your file that starts with PrivateKey and the file from CSS.

trans-unit.source: For example:
trans-unit.target: For example:

trans-unit.source: The output of this command should be two files: One contains the plaintext password for the password-protected TPD, and the other is the password-protected TPD itself.
trans-unit.target: The output of this command should be two files: One contains the plaintext password for the password-protected TPD, and the other is the password-protected TPD itself.

trans-unit.source: For cross-referencing purposes, both should have the same GUID as the public and private key files from when you ran the AadrmTpd.exe -createkey command:
trans-unit.target: For cross-referencing purposes, both should have the same GUID as the public and private key files from when you ran the AadrmTpd.exe -createkey command:

trans-unit.source: Password-FA29D0FE-5049-4C8E-931B-96C6152B0441.txt
trans-unit.target: Password-FA29D0FE-5049-4C8E-931B-96C6152B0441.txt

trans-unit.source: ExportedTPD-FA29D0FE-5049-4C8E-931B-96C6152B0441.xml
trans-unit.target: ExportedTPD-FA29D0FE-5049-4C8E-931B-96C6152B0441.xml

trans-unit.source: Backup these files and store them safely to ensure that you can continue to decrypt content that is protected with this tenant key.
trans-unit.target: Backup these files and store them safely to ensure that you can continue to decrypt content that is protected with this tenant key.

trans-unit.source: In addition, if you are migrating to AD RMS, you can import this TPD file (the file that starts with ExportedTDP) to your AD RMS server.
trans-unit.target: In addition, if you are migrating to AD RMS, you can import this TPD file (the file that starts with ExportedTDP) to your AD RMS server.

trans-unit.source: Step 4: Ongoing: Protect your tenant key
trans-unit.target: Step 4: Ongoing: Protect your tenant key

trans-unit.source: After you receive your tenant key, keep it well-guarded, because if somebody gets access to it, they can decrypt all documents that are protected by using that key.
trans-unit.target: After you receive your tenant key, keep it well-guarded, because if somebody gets access to it, they can decrypt all documents that are protected by using that key.

trans-unit.source: If the reason for exporting your tenant key is because you no longer want to use Azure RMS, as a best practice, now deactivate your RMS tenant.
trans-unit.target: If the reason for exporting your tenant key is because you no longer want to use Azure RMS, as a best practice, now deactivate your RMS tenant.

trans-unit.source: Do not delay doing this after you receive your tenant key because this precaution will help to minimize the consequences if your tenant key is accessed by somebody who should not have it.
trans-unit.target: Do not delay doing this after you receive your tenant key because this precaution will help to minimize the consequences if your tenant key is accessed by somebody who should not have it.

trans-unit.source: For instructions, see <link><linkText>Decommissioning and Deactivating Azure Rights Management</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For instructions, see <link><linkText>Decommissioning and Deactivating Azure Rights Management</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Respond to a breach
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Respond to a breach

trans-unit.source: No security system, no matter how strong, is complete without a breach response process.
trans-unit.target: No security system, no matter how strong, is complete without a breach response process.

trans-unit.source: Your tenant key might be compromised or stolen.
trans-unit.target: Your tenant key might be compromised or stolen.

trans-unit.source: Even when it’s well protected well, vulnerabilities might be found in current generation HSM technology or current key lengths and algorithms.
trans-unit.target: Even when it’s well protected well, vulnerabilities might be found in current generation HSM technology or current key lengths and algorithms.

trans-unit.source: Microsoft has a dedicated team to respond to security incidents in its products and services.
trans-unit.target: Microsoft has a dedicated team to respond to security incidents in its products and services.

trans-unit.source: As soon as there is a credible report of an incident, this team engages to investigate the scope, root cause, and mitigations.
trans-unit.target: As soon as there is a credible report of an incident, this team engages to investigate the scope, root cause, and mitigations.

trans-unit.source: If this incident affects your assets, then Microsoft will notify your Azure RMS tenant administrators by email by using the address that you supplied when you subscribed.
trans-unit.target: If this incident affects your assets, then Microsoft will notify your Azure RMS tenant administrators by email by using the address that you supplied when you subscribed.

trans-unit.source: If you have a breach, the best action that you or Microsoft can take depends on the scope of the breach; Microsoft will work with you through this process.
trans-unit.target: If you have a breach, the best action that you or Microsoft can take depends on the scope of the breach; Microsoft will work with you through this process.

trans-unit.source: The following table shows some typical situations and the likely response, although the exact response will depend on all the information that is revealed during the investigation.
trans-unit.target: The following table shows some typical situations and the likely response, although the exact response will depend on all the information that is revealed during the investigation.

trans-unit.source: Incident description
trans-unit.target: Incident description

trans-unit.source: Likely response
trans-unit.target: Likely response

trans-unit.source: Your tenant key is leaked.
trans-unit.target: Your tenant key is leaked.

trans-unit.source: Re-key your tenant key.
trans-unit.target: Re-key your tenant key.

trans-unit.source: See the <link><linkText>Re-key your tenant key</linkText><title></title></link> section in this topic.
trans-unit.target: See the <link><linkText>Re-key your tenant key</linkText><title></title></link> section in this topic.

trans-unit.source: An unauthorized individual or malware got rights to use your tenant key but the key itself did not leak.
trans-unit.target: An unauthorized individual or malware got rights to use your tenant key but the key itself did not leak.

trans-unit.source: Re-keying your tenant key does not help here and requires root-cause analysis.
trans-unit.target: Re-keying your tenant key does not help here and requires root-cause analysis.

trans-unit.source: If a process or software bug was responsible for the unauthorized individual to get access, that situation must be resolved.
trans-unit.target: If a process or software bug was responsible for the unauthorized individual to get access, that situation must be resolved.

trans-unit.source: Vulnerability discovered in the RSA algorithm, or key length, or brute-force attacks become computationally feasible.
trans-unit.target: Vulnerability discovered in the RSA algorithm, or key length, or brute-force attacks become computationally feasible.

trans-unit.source: Microsoft must update the Azure RMS to support new algorithms and longer key lengths that are resilient, and instruct all customers to renew their tenant keys.
trans-unit.target: Microsoft must update the Azure RMS to support new algorithms and longer key lengths that are resilient, and instruct all customers to renew their tenant keys.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Customer-managed: Tenant key lifecycle operations
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Customer-managed: Tenant key lifecycle operations

trans-unit.source: If you manage your tenant key for Azure Rights Management (the bring your own key, or BYOK, scenario), use the following sections for more information about the lifecycle operations that are relevant to this topology:
trans-unit.target: If you manage your tenant key for Azure Rights Management (the bring your own key, or BYOK, scenario), use the following sections for more information about the lifecycle operations that are relevant to this topology:

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Revoke your tenant key</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Revoke your tenant key</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Re-key your tenant key</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Re-key your tenant key</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Backup and recover your tenant key</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Backup and recover your tenant key</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Export your tenant key</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Export your tenant key</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Respond to a breach</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Respond to a breach</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Revoke your tenant key
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Revoke your tenant key

trans-unit.source: When you unsubscribe from Azure RMS, Azure RMS stops using your tenant key and no action is needed from you.
trans-unit.target: When you unsubscribe from Azure RMS, Azure RMS stops using your tenant key and no action is needed from you.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Re-key your tenant key
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Re-key your tenant key

trans-unit.source: Re-keying is also known as rolling your key.
trans-unit.target: Re-keying is also known as rolling your key.

trans-unit.source: Do not re-key your tenant key unless it’s really necessary.
trans-unit.target: Do not re-key your tenant key unless it’s really necessary.

trans-unit.source: Older clients, such as Office 2010, were not designed to handle key changes gracefully.
trans-unit.target: Older clients, such as Office 2010, were not designed to handle key changes gracefully.

trans-unit.source: In this scenario, you must clear the RMS state on computers by using Group Policy or an equivalent mechanism.
trans-unit.target: In this scenario, you must clear the RMS state on computers by using Group Policy or an equivalent mechanism.

trans-unit.source: However, there are some legitimate events that may force you to re-key your tenant key.
trans-unit.target: However, there are some legitimate events that may force you to re-key your tenant key.

trans-unit.source: For example:
trans-unit.target: For example:

trans-unit.source: Your company has split into two or more companies.
trans-unit.target: Your company has split into two or more companies.

trans-unit.source: When you re-key your tenant key, the new company will not have access to new content that your employees publish.
trans-unit.target: When you re-key your tenant key, the new company will not have access to new content that your employees publish.

trans-unit.source: They can access the old content if they have a copy of the old tenant key.
trans-unit.target: They can access the old content if they have a copy of the old tenant key.

trans-unit.source: You believe the master copy of your tenant key (the copy in your possession) was compromised.
trans-unit.target: You believe the master copy of your tenant key (the copy in your possession) was compromised.

trans-unit.source: When you re-key your tenant key, new content is protected by using the new tenant key.
trans-unit.target: When you re-key your tenant key, new content is protected by using the new tenant key.

trans-unit.source: This happens in a phased manner, so for a period of time, some new content will continue to be protected with the old tenant key.
trans-unit.target: This happens in a phased manner, so for a period of time, some new content will continue to be protected with the old tenant key.

trans-unit.source: Previously protected content stays protected to your old tenant key.
trans-unit.target: Previously protected content stays protected to your old tenant key.

trans-unit.source: To support this scenario, Azure RMS retains your old tenant key so that it can issue licenses for old content.
trans-unit.target: To support this scenario, Azure RMS retains your old tenant key so that it can issue licenses for old content.

trans-unit.source: To re-key your tenant key, generate and create a new key over the Internet or in person, by using the procedures in the <link><linkText>Implementing bring your own key (BYOK)</linkText><title></title></link> section from the <link><linkText>Planning and Implementing Your Azure Rights Management Tenant Key</linkText><title></title></link> topic.
trans-unit.target: To re-key your tenant key, generate and create a new key over the Internet or in person, by using the procedures in the <link><linkText>Implementing bring your own key (BYOK)</linkText><title></title></link> section from the <link><linkText>Planning and Implementing Your Azure Rights Management Tenant Key</linkText><title></title></link> topic.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Backup and recover your tenant key
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Backup and recover your tenant key

trans-unit.source: You are responsible for backing up your tenant key.
trans-unit.target: You are responsible for backing up your tenant key.

trans-unit.source: If you generated your tenant key in a Thales HSM, to back up the key, just back up the Tokenized Key file, the World file, and the Administrator Cards.
trans-unit.target: If you generated your tenant key in a Thales HSM, to back up the key, just back up the Tokenized Key file, the World file, and the Administrator Cards.

trans-unit.source: If you transferred your key by following the procedures in the <link><linkText>Implementing bring your own key (BYOK)</linkText><title></title></link> section from the <link><linkText>Planning and Implementing Your Azure Rights Management Tenant Key</linkText><title></title></link> topic, Azure RMS will persist the Tokenized Key File, to protect against failure of any Azure RMS nodes.
trans-unit.target: If you transferred your key by following the procedures in the <link><linkText>Implementing bring your own key (BYOK)</linkText><title></title></link> section from the <link><linkText>Planning and Implementing Your Azure Rights Management Tenant Key</linkText><title></title></link> topic, Azure RMS will persist the Tokenized Key File, to protect against failure of any Azure RMS nodes.

trans-unit.source: However, do not consider this to be a full backup.
trans-unit.target: However, do not consider this to be a full backup.

trans-unit.source: For example, if you ever need a plaintext copy of your key to use outside a Thales HSM, Azure RMS will not be able to retrieve it for you because it only has a non-recoverable copy.
trans-unit.target: For example, if you ever need a plaintext copy of your key to use outside a Thales HSM, Azure RMS will not be able to retrieve it for you because it only has a non-recoverable copy.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Export your tenant key
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Export your tenant key

trans-unit.source: If you use BYOK, you cannot export your tenant key from Azure RMS.
trans-unit.target: If you use BYOK, you cannot export your tenant key from Azure RMS.

trans-unit.source: The copy in Azure RMS is non-recoverable.
trans-unit.target: The copy in Azure RMS is non-recoverable.

trans-unit.source: If you want to delete this key so it can no longer be used, contact Microsoft Customer Service Support (CSS).
trans-unit.target: If you want to delete this key so it can no longer be used, contact Microsoft Customer Service Support (CSS).

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Respond to a breach
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Respond to a breach

trans-unit.source: No security system, no matter how strong, is complete without a breach response process.
trans-unit.target: No security system, no matter how strong, is complete without a breach response process.

trans-unit.source: Your tenant key might be compromised or stolen.
trans-unit.target: Your tenant key might be compromised or stolen.

trans-unit.source: Even when it’s well protected well, vulnerabilities might be found in current generation HSM technology or current key lengths and algorithms.
trans-unit.target: Even when it’s well protected well, vulnerabilities might be found in current generation HSM technology or current key lengths and algorithms.

trans-unit.source: Microsoft has a dedicated team to respond to security incidents in its products and services.
trans-unit.target: Microsoft has a dedicated team to respond to security incidents in its products and services.

trans-unit.source: As soon as there is a credible report of an incident, this team engages to investigate the scope, root cause, and mitigations.
trans-unit.target: As soon as there is a credible report of an incident, this team engages to investigate the scope, root cause, and mitigations.

trans-unit.source: If this incident affects your assets, then Microsoft will notify your Azure RMS tenant administrators by email by using the address that you supplied when you subscribed.
trans-unit.target: If this incident affects your assets, then Microsoft will notify your Azure RMS tenant administrators by email by using the address that you supplied when you subscribed.

trans-unit.source: If you have a breach, the best action that you or Microsoft can take depends on the scope of the breach; Microsoft will work with you through this process.
trans-unit.target: If you have a breach, the best action that you or Microsoft can take depends on the scope of the breach; Microsoft will work with you through this process.

trans-unit.source: The following table shows some typical situations and the likely response, although the exact response will depend on all the information that is revealed during the investigation.
trans-unit.target: The following table shows some typical situations and the likely response, although the exact response will depend on all the information that is revealed during the investigation.

trans-unit.source: Incident description
trans-unit.target: Incident description

trans-unit.source: Likely response
trans-unit.target: Likely response

trans-unit.source: Your tenant key is leaked.
trans-unit.target: Your tenant key is leaked.

trans-unit.source: Re-key your tenant key.
trans-unit.target: Re-key your tenant key.

trans-unit.source: See the <link><linkText>Re-key your tenant key</linkText><title></title></link> section in this topic.
trans-unit.target: See the <link><linkText>Re-key your tenant key</linkText><title></title></link> section in this topic.

trans-unit.source: An unauthorized individual or malware got rights to use your tenant key but the key itself did not leak.
trans-unit.target: An unauthorized individual or malware got rights to use your tenant key but the key itself did not leak.

trans-unit.source: Re-keying your tenant key does not help here and requires root-cause analysis.
trans-unit.target: Re-keying your tenant key does not help here and requires root-cause analysis.

trans-unit.source: If a process or software bug was responsible for the unauthorized individual to get access, that situation must be resolved.
trans-unit.target: If a process or software bug was responsible for the unauthorized individual to get access, that situation must be resolved.

trans-unit.source: Vulnerability discovered in the current-generation HSM technology.
trans-unit.target: Vulnerability discovered in the current-generation HSM technology.

trans-unit.source: Microsoft must update the HSMs.
trans-unit.target: Microsoft must update the HSMs.

trans-unit.source: If there is reason to believe that the vulnerability exposed keys, then Microsoft will instruct all customers to renew their tenant keys.
trans-unit.target: If there is reason to believe that the vulnerability exposed keys, then Microsoft will instruct all customers to renew their tenant keys.

trans-unit.source: Vulnerability discovered in the RSA algorithm, or key length, or brute-force attacks become computationally feasible.
trans-unit.target: Vulnerability discovered in the RSA algorithm, or key length, or brute-force attacks become computationally feasible.

trans-unit.source: Microsoft must update the Azure RMS to support new algorithms and longer key lengths that are resilient, and instruct all customers to renew their tenant keys.
trans-unit.target: Microsoft must update the Azure RMS to support new algorithms and longer key lengths that are resilient, and instruct all customers to renew their tenant keys.

trans-unit.source: See Also
trans-unit.target: See Also
